title: Controversial celeb Halloween costumes from Lily Allen to Hilary Duff
text:
Celebrities have had some questionable outfits over the years (Picture: Rex; Ashley Tisdale/Instagram; FameFlynet)

There comes a time every Halloween when it seems like celebrities are determined to outdo each other.

While some go for sexy or spooky costumes, others pay homage to their friends and pop culture icons.

And some are just downright baffling, to be honest.

However, in their mission to come up with the most original costume, some famous faces have inevitably gone too far, causing controversy and even offense.

Lily Allen’s Dr Luke

People weren’t impressed by this (Picture: Rex Features)

In one of the most bizarre decisions of all time, Lily Allen decided to dress as producer Dr Luke for a Halloween party in 2014 – right after Kesha accused him of sexual assault.

Dr Luke denied the claims and Kesha went on to drop the case.

However, people were less than impressed when Lily dressed in an outfit that imitated scrubs, donning a name tag that read ‘Dr Luke Gynecology Department’ for Kate Hudson’s Halloween bash.

Understandably, fans and critics alike called her out for trivialising the issue.

Ashley Tisdale’s Day Of The Dead

Ashley was accused of appropriation (Picture: Ashley Tisdale/Instagram)

Ashley Tisdale has made a name for herself as a family friendly star after her success in the High School Musical movies.

However, she faced controversy back in 2016 for her Day Of The Dead skull costume, which appeared to be based on the Mexican tradition which is used to honour deceased relatives.

Some accused her of appropriating Mexican culture with the costume, with one critic commenting: ‘This is disgusting.’

‘I love her and think she is stunning but with all the options available why choose something a culture uses to respect their dead family and ancestors??’ another asked.

Luann de Lesseps’ Diana Ross

She was encouraged not to try this one again… (Picture: Luann de Lesseps/Instagram)

Real Housewives Of New York City star Luann de Lesseps also came under fire when she appeared to use blackface for a Diana Ross costume back in 2018.

The star donned a huge wig, as well as a white jumpsuit, writing on Instagram: ‘New hair, new me. I’m coming out #hair #hairstyle #inspired #DianaRoss.’

However, people weren’t happy, with some branding her ‘racist’ and others simply commenting: ‘Don’t try this again.’

Sound advice TBH.

Luann later apologised for the costume on Watch What Happens Live, saying: ‘I had bronzer on that I wear normally like the rest of my skin. I’m tan, like right now.

‘So I didn’t add anything or would ever, ever dream of doing a blackface. Ever … I’m very sorry to everyone out there if I offended anyone.’

Hilary Duff’s Pilgrim

Hilary later issued an apology (Picture: 2016 Getty Images)

Hilary Duff can simply not have been thinking straight when she and her boyfriend at the time Jason Walsh decided to dress up as a ‘pilgrim and an Indian’.

Yep.

The Lizzie McGuire star faced controversy when she donned the offensive look for the Casmigos Halloween party in 2016 and later issued an apology.

‘I am SO sorry to people I offended with my costume. It was not properly thought through and I am truly, from the bottom of my [heart emoji] sorry,’ she wrote.

The star added: ‘I meant no disrespect. I only have admiration for the indigenous people of America.’

Julianne Hough’s Crazy Eyes

This offended many (Picture: FameFlynet.uk.com)

We all love a bit of Orange Is The New Black, but there’s a time and a place – and this was neither.

Dancing With The Stars’ Julianne Hough had people shocked in 2013 when she wore blackface to dress up as Suzanne ‘Crazy Eyes’ Warren.

The star also had her hair up in an imitation of the character’s style and donned an orange jumpsuit.

After facing backlash, she issued an apology, writing on Twitter: ‘I am a huge fan of the show ‘Orange is the New black,’ actress Uzo Aduba, and the character she has created.

‘It certainly was never my intention to be disrespectful or demeaning to anyone in any way. I realize my costume hurt and offended people and I truly apologize. [sic]’

Jaclyn Hill’s ‘cancelled’ dress

One of the latest entries (Picture: @jaclynhill)

Jaclyn Hill has kicked off this year’s controversial costumes, with her ‘cancelled’ dress.

The YouTube star, who was criticised for her beauty range earlier this year, donned a dress emblazoned with the words ‘Jaclyn Hill is cancelled.’

‘Over the last several years the internet has become more & more cruel & has developed what we now call “cancel culture” not one day has gone by in over 2 years where I have not seen “you’re canceled” online,’ she wrote, explaining the costume.

‘I wanted to create a look showing the glam side of this industry & the ugly [skull emoji]. So here is it. You want me canceled? You got it baby.

‘And I know my “haters” are going to HATE this costume. But that’s okay, I love you anyway.’

However, some weren’t happy with the costume, with one Twitter user writing: ‘Jaclyn Hill dressing up as someone who is cancelled for Halloween just shows how out of touch with reality she is.’

Honourable mention to Tana Mongeau’s scantily clad JoJo Siwa

Tana Mongeau is no stranger to a sexy outfit but it was said she took it too far when she dressed as ‘Hoe Hoe Siwa’, a take on her fellow YouTuber JoJo Siwa.

Safe to say, people were less than impressed by her take on the costume, which saw her scantily clad as the 16-year-old in just a bra, thong, tutu and fish-net tights.

Advertisement

Many criticised her for sexualising Jojo, who usually dresses in t-shirts and hoodies, with her trademark side ponytail.

However, Tana went on to defend the look, reasoning it was never her intention to sexualise her friend.

‘Saw some tweets about my Jojo costume and I just wanna clarify before things get crazy- Jojo is a great friend of mine & I would never intend to sexualize HER, I literally think that anything like that is gross as f***,’ she said.

‘It was just like a slutty schoolgirl costume, girl scout, or cheerleader to me,’ she continued. ‘I totally didn’t see it that way and would never want to! I LOVE Jojo and making crazy halloween costumes and she was telling me to do it! just wanted to let u know my standpoint on that before I see anything else.’

When the backlash continued, Tana apologised, saying: ‘I’m so sorry if my Jojo costume upset anyone in any way. I had no nasty or ill intentions and Jojo is a good friend of mine who didn’t have a problem.

‘Lesson learned! I love Jojo & yall & Halloween costumes and def will think harder next year about ALL possibilities of a costume.’
